title: Region 5 : Unova
text:
Unova marks a departure from Japan-inspired regions, drawing influence from the United States, particularly New York City and its surrounding areas. The region is highly urbanized, featuring massive skyscrapers, industrial zones, and expansive bridges that connect key locations. Castelia City, the region’s centerpiece, is a vast metropolis with bustling streets, emphasizing the fast-paced lifestyle of a major American city. Unova’s design is more linear than that of previous regions, with well-defined routes and highways leading between significant settlements. However, the area also features diverse environments, including deserts, marshlands, and forests, showcasing the landscapes in the northeastern U.S.
Beyond its urban influence, Unova embodies change, conflict, and societal evolution themes. The region’s story revolves around ideological clashes, mirroring real-world debates about progress, tradition, and morality. The Legendary Pokémon Reshiram and Zekrom symbolize these opposing ideologies, representing truth and ideals, respectively. The region also introduces a more narrative-driven experience, with Team Plasma acting as a philosophical antagonist rather than a typical criminal organization. Team Plasma’s goal is to liberate Pokémon from human control, sparking a debate about the ethical treatment of Pokémon. Unova’s worldbuilding reflects the grandeur and complexity of modern society, making it a dynamic and alive region.

title: Region 5 : Unova
text:
Pokémon Type Distribution









This demonstration explores the distribution of Pokémon types across different regions, revealing how geography and environment influence the Pokémon world. By analyzing type frequency by region, users can identify patterns in how certain types thrive in specific landscapes. The interactive visualizations allow trainers to compare regional ecosystems, uncover trends, and gain a deeper understanding of the relationship between Pokémon habitats and their elemental traits. Designed for educators, researchers, and enthusiasts, this resource bridges the gap between game-play and data analysis, offering an engaging and accessible way to explore Pokémon metadata.
Understanding the distribution of Pokémon types across different regions provides valuable insight into how geography and environment shape the Pokémon world. By analyzing type frequency by region, we can identify patterns in how certain types thrive in specific landscapes. This analysis highlights the ecological diversity within each region and deepens our understanding of how Pokémon adapt to their surroundings. Beyond identifying patterns, this analysis enhances strategic decision-making for trainers and researchers. Understanding which types are most common in each region can help trainers anticipate challenges, build balanced teams, and appreciate the environmental influences on Pokémon availability. For researchers, these insights provide a deeper look into how the Pokémon world mirrors real-world biodiversity, reinforcing the connection between habitat, adaptation, and survival. By engaging with this data, users can uncover new perspectives on the Pokémon universe and explore the dynamic relationship between nature and Pokémon distribution.

title: Region 5 : Unova
text:
Pokémon Attribute Distribution

HealthAttackAttack+DefenseDefense+SpeedTotal
















































































This analysis examines the distribution of Pokémon attributes, such as base stats, abilities, and typing, across different regions, revealing how these characteristics vary based on regional environments and design philosophies. By evaluating attribute frequency and stat distributions, users can uncover trends in how Pokémon are balanced within their ecosystems. Interactive visualizations allow trainers to compare regional averages, explore outliers, and gain insights into how different factors—such as habitat, evolution, and competitive viability—shape the distribution of Pokémon attributes. This resource is designed for educators, researchers, and enthusiasts, offering an engaging and accessible approach to exploring Pokémon metadata through statistical analysis.
Understanding the distribution of Pokémon attributes across regions provides valuable insights into game design and strategic planning. By analyzing patterns in base stats, ability prevalence, and type distributions, we can observe how certain attributes are emphasized in specific areas. This analysis highlights regional variation in Pokémon design, from power scaling in later generations to introducing unique abilities that reflect environmental adaptation. By studying these differences, we can better appreciate how Pokémon attributes evolve over time and across different settings. Beyond identifying trends, this analysis enhances strategic decision-making for trainers and researchers. Understanding which stat distributions and abilities are most common in each region helps trainers optimize team compositions, anticipate battle dynamics, and adapt to competitive landscapes. For researchers, these findings provide a data-driven perspective on how the Pokémon series develops its in-game ecosystems, reinforcing the connection between game mechanics, regional themes, and attribute balance. By engaging with this data, users can uncover new perspectives on the Pokémon universe and explore the intricate relationship between Pokémon attributes and their designed environments.

title: Region 6 : Kalos
text:
France inspires Kalos, particularly its emphasis on beauty, art, and history. The region’s diverse geography features scenic countryside, sprawling cities, and a majestic mountain range that divides the land. Lumiose City, the largest city in Kalos, mirrors Paris with its grand boulevards, cafés, and an Eiffel Tower-inspired landmark, the Prism Tower. The region’s routes are designed with a picturesque quality, featuring rolling hills, flower fields, and vineyard-like landscapes. Kalos emphasizes elegance in its architecture, town layouts, and Pokémon designs, reflecting the cultural refinement often associated with France.
Beyond aesthetics, Kalos carries a theme of war and rebirth, evident in its backstory, which involves an ancient conflict and the mysterious ultimate weapon. The contrast between beauty and destruction is central to Kalos’ identity, with Lysandre and Team Flare aiming to control or purify the world through extreme measures. The Legendary Pokémon Xerneas and Yveltal symbolize life and destruction, reinforcing this duality. Kalos presents a visually stunning and prosperous region, exploring more profound history, conflict, and cultural pride themes.

title: Region 7 : Alola
text:
Alola is based on the Hawaiian Islands, featuring a tropical archipelago with distinct islands, each offering unique biomes. The region departs from the traditional Pokémon League structure, replacing it with the Island Challenge, which reflects the real-world cultural practices of Hawaiian rites of passage. Alola’s environment is vibrant, with active volcanoes, lush jungles, coral reefs, and sandy beaches. The region’s towns and settlements are designed to blend seamlessly with nature, emphasizing an eco-friendly and harmonious way of life.
The inspiration behind Alola extends beyond its geography to its culture and mythology. The Tapu guardians resemble Hawaiian deities, protecting each island while deeply ingrained in local traditions. The Legendary Pokémon Solgaleo and Lunala represent celestial forces, further enhancing the region’s spiritual undertones. Alola’s relaxed atmosphere and strong sense of community create an immersive experience, making it one of the most culturally distinct Pokémon regions.

title: Region 2 : Johto
text:
Johto is deeply influenced by Japan’s Kansai and Chūbu regions, featuring traditional Japanese aesthetics and a rich cultural history. Unlike Kanto’s industrialized look, Johto strongly emphasizes nature and heritage, with serene countryside towns, ancient towers, and sprawling fields. Landmarks like Ecruteak City’s Burned Tower and Bell Tower evoke historical mysticism, while areas such as the Ruins of Alph reinforce the region’s connection to ancient civilizations. Johto’s routes are more organic in layout, with more curves and natural barriers, emphasizing a stronger bond between humans and nature.
The region’s inspiration stems from traditional Japan, particularly the Edo period when nature and spirituality played a vital role in daily life. Many towns feature Japanese-style architecture, pagodas, and shrines, reinforcing a historical aesthetic. The Legendary Pokémon Ho-Oh and Lugia represent spiritual guardians akin to deities of ancient mythologies. This deep connection to the past is further reflected in Johto’s folklore, including stories of the three legendary beasts and the ancient Unown language. Johto’s design is imbued with a sense of nostalgia and reverence, offering a journey deeply rooted in history and mythology.

title: Region 1 : Kanto
text:
Kanto, the first Pokémon region introduced, is heavily inspired by the real-world Kantō region of Japan. Its landscape features a mix of urban and rural environments, with densely populated cities, small countryside towns, vast forests, and coastal routes. The region’s topography is relatively straightforward, with no extreme geographical features like mountains or deserts. Kanto has a structured, grid-like design, reflecting early Pokémon games’ simplicity. Verdant forests like Viridian and coastal areas like Cinnabar Island contribute to the region’s biodiversity. At the same time, the presence of man-made locations like the Power Plant, a key source of energy for the region, and Pokémon Mansion, a symbol of wealth and technological advancement, highlight a blend of nature and industrialization.
The region’s inspiration draws from early post-war Japan, where urban expansion and technological advancement reshaped the landscape. This can be seen in locations such as Saffron City, a significant metropolis housing the mighty Silph Co., and Celadon City, which boasts a massive department store and a casino. The emphasis on scientific research, seen in Cinnabar’s Pokémon Lab and Mewtwo’s creation, aligns with Japan’s rapid technological growth. Kanto’s simple but structured environment reflects an era of transformation, where nature coexists with emerging urban development, setting the stage for later, more diverse Pokémon regions.

title: Region 9 : Paldea
text:
Paldea is inspired by the Iberian Peninsula, encompassing Spain and Portugal’s rich history, warm climate, and vibrant cultures. Unlike previous regions, Paldea features a vast open-world design with expansive plains, rugged mountain ranges, and picturesque coastal towns. The area is characterized by its terracotta-roofed villages, sun-soaked vineyards, and grand plazas reminiscent of Mediterranean architecture. Central to Paldea’s design is the Great Crater of Paldea, a massive geological landmark that serves as both a scientific enigma and a key narrative element. The diverse biomes include arid deserts, lush olive groves, and volcanic peaks, reflecting the natural beauty of the Iberian landscape. Cities like Mesagoza, which houses a prestigious academy, take inspiration from renowned Spanish universities, while other towns pay homage to Spain’s lively fiestas and traditional marketplaces.
Paldea’s cultural themes emphasize exploration, education, and self-discovery. The Academy system plays a central role in the region, encouraging players to embark on an academic journey inspired by Spain’s strong emphasis on learning and tradition. The three distinct story paths—Victory Road, Starfall Street, and the Path of Legends—offer a non-linear approach to storytelling, mirroring the idea of choosing one’s own path in life. Paldea’s Legendary Pokémon, Koraidon and Miraidon, represent different eras of history, highlighting the region’s fascination with time, innovation, and blending past and future. The influence of Spanish folklore is seen in the designs of Pokémon such as Flamigo, which resembles the national bird of Spain, and the use of architectural motifs reminiscent of Gaudí’s work in places like the art-filled Levincia. With its warm color palette, lively culture, and emphasis on independence, Paldea stands out as a region that celebrates the joy of discovery and the deep historical roots of the Iberian world.

title: Region 8 : Galar
text:
Galar is heavily inspired by the United Kingdom, featuring a rich blend of industrial cities, historic sites, and rolling countryside. The region’s geography is structured along a vertical axis, reflecting the elongated shape of Great Britain, with its capital, Wyndon, positioned at the northernmost point, similar to London. The landscape varies from the sprawling farmlands of the southern Wild Area to the misty forests and towering cliffs of the northern routes. Towns and cities showcase a mix of medieval architecture, brick-built industrial factories, and grand stadiums, emphasizing the region’s strong ties to history, industry, and sports culture. Including train stations and an underground railway system also reflects Britain’s extensive transportation network, while locales like Ballonlea, with its bioluminescent mushroom forests, add a touch of fantasy.
Galar’s culture and themes revolve around competition, industry, and heritage. The region is deeply influenced by the UK’s passion for sports, mainly soccer, which is reflected in the Gym Challenge, where battles occur in massive stadiums with roaring crowds. The industrial revolution’s impact is evident in cities like Motostoke, where towering smokestacks and metal bridges symbolize Galar’s working-class roots. Ancient ruins and mysterious relics, such as the murals in Stow-on-Side, highlight Galar’s profound historical lore, drawing inspiration from British legends like King Arthur and the Stonehenge monuments. Legendary Pokémon Zacian and Zamazenta embody knightly chivalry, reinforcing the region’s medieval influences. With a narrative focused on tradition versus progress, Galar presents a world where past and present collide, shaping an area deeply rooted in its historical and cultural legacy.

title: Welcome Trainer!
text:
Pokémon Data Center
This resource is an interactive codebook designed to make exploring the Pokédex intuitive, engaging, and accessible for all users. Unlike traditional static codebooks that simply provide information, this interactive version allows users to engage directly with the data. This dynamic approach makes it easier to analyze patterns, compare Pokémon attributes, and gain insights in real-time. Whether you are a researcher, educator, or enthusiast, this codebook offers a seamless way to navigate the Pokédex, providing both an educational and enjoyable experience. Furthermore, this resource emphasizes convenience and cost-effectiveness. As an open-access tool available online, it eliminates the need for expensive software or exclusive memberships. Users can explore the Pokédex freely, making this codebook an invaluable asset for independent learners, educators designing coursework, or researchers conducting statistical analyses.
This resource will be valuable for trainers of all backgrounds interested in data analysis. As I continue to develop the data center, we can improve this resource together. I encourage trainers to regularly utilize this resource to practice their data analysis skills.

title: About
text:
About this site

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: Region 3 : Hoenn
text:
Hoenn is a region of vast environmental diversity, featuring lush rainforests, volcanic landscapes, vast ocean routes, and arid deserts. It draws heavy inspiration from the Kyushu region of Japan, known for its rugged geography and subtropical climate. The Hoenn region boasts some of the most varied biomes in the Pokémon world, from the active Mt. Chimney to the waterlogged depths of Sootopolis City. This diversity emphasizes a strong connection between Pokémon and their environments, showcasing how different ecosystems can shape life. The routes are more complex, integrating environmental obstacles such as currents, caves, and ash-covered terrain.
Hoenn’s design philosophy reflects the beauty and volatility of nature. Towns are often built harmoniously with their surroundings, such as Fortree City’s treetop homes or Pacifidlog Town’s floating structures. Hoenn’s story also emphasizes the power and danger of natural elements, with the conflict between Team Aqua and Team Magma centering around climate manipulation. The Legendary Pokémon Kyogre, Groudon, and Rayquaza embody different forces of nature—water, land, and sky—reinforcing Hoenn’s environmental themes. This region highlights the balance between civilization and nature’s raw, untamed power, offering a unique and immersive experience.

text:
Pokémon Attribute Distribution

HealthAttackAttack+DefenseDefense+SpeedTotal
















































































This analysis examines the distribution of Pokémon attributes, such as base stats, abilities, and typing, across different regions, revealing how these characteristics vary based on regional environments and design philosophies. By evaluating attribute frequency and stat distributions, users can uncover trends in how Pokémon are balanced within their ecosystems. Interactive visualizations allow trainers to compare regional averages, explore outliers, and gain insights into how different factors—such as habitat, evolution, and competitive viability—shape the distribution of Pokémon attributes. This resource is designed for educators, researchers, and enthusiasts, offering an engaging and accessible approach to exploring Pokémon metadata through statistical analysis.
Understanding the distribution of Pokémon attributes across regions provides valuable insights into game design and strategic planning. By analyzing patterns in base stats, ability prevalence, and type distributions, we can observe how certain attributes are emphasized in specific areas. This analysis highlights regional variation in Pokémon design, from power scaling in later generations to introducing unique abilities that reflect environmental adaptation. By studying these differences, we can better appreciate how Pokémon attributes evolve over time and across different settings. Beyond identifying trends, this analysis enhances strategic decision-making for trainers and researchers. Understanding which stat distributions and abilities are most common in each region helps trainers optimize team compositions, anticipate battle dynamics, and adapt to competitive landscapes. For researchers, these findings provide a data-driven perspective on how the Pokémon series develops its in-game ecosystems, reinforcing the connection between game mechanics, regional themes, and attribute balance. By engaging with this data, users can uncover new perspectives on the Pokémon universe and explore the intricate relationship between Pokémon attributes and their designed environments.

title: Welcome Trainer!
text:
Markup, Markdown
Markdown is a lightweight markup language designed for creating formatted text using a simple, readable syntax. Without relying on word processors, it allows users to structure documents with headings, lists, links, code chunks, code blocks, and other elements. Primarily used for documentation, blogging, and technical writing, Markdown is widely supported across platforms, making it an efficient and versatile tool for writing content that can be easily converted into HTML, PDFs, or other formats.

Quarto
Quarto is a powerful, multi-language publishing system designed to be the next-generation evolution of R Markdown. Posit PBC acquired RStudio in November 2022 and introduced Quarto, an enhanced dynamic and reproducible document creation tool, without plans to deprecate R Markdown or R Notebook. This ensures that long-time users of R Markdown can continue using their existing workflows while benefiting from Quarto’s expanded capabilities. Quarto provides seamless support for multiple programming languages, including R, Python, Julia, and Observable JavaScript, making it a flexible solution for data scientists, researchers, and analysts across different platforms. With a strong emphasis on accessibility and ease of use, Quarto maintains an interface and command structure nearly identical to R Markdown, allowing users to transition smoothly.
One of Quarto’s most notable strengths is its diverse output formats, enabling users to create high-quality PDFs, interactive websites, presentations, dashboards, and web applications. Its enhanced publishing options make it well-suited for producing technical reports, academic papers, books, and scientific journals. Additionally, Quarto integrates well with modern tools like GitHub Pages and Decap (Netlify), streamlining the process of sharing results with a broader audience. With these improvements, Quarto represents a significant step forward in dynamic document generation. It offers greater flexibility, multi-language functionality, and a wider range of publishing capabilities while retaining the familiarity of R Markdown for existing users.

Create a Document
Creating a document in Quarto (.qmd file) involves a straightforward process that combines Markdown for text formatting, code chunks for computation, and YAML metadata for document configuration. To start, you first need to install Quarto on your system and ensure it is properly set up. Once installed, you can create a new .qmd file using any text editor, such as VS Code or RStudio. The .qmd file serves as a structured document where you can write formatted text, embed code, and generate outputs like HTML, PDF, or Word documents.
A Quarto document typically begins with a YAML header, enclosed by triple dashes (---). This header defines metadata such as the document’s title, author, format, and other settings. For example, a basic YAML header might look like this:





Below the YAML header, you can write content using Markdown syntax to structure headings, lists, tables, and inline formatting. You can also embed code chunks using languages like R or Python. Code chunks are enclosed within triple backticks (```) and specify the programming language used. For instance, an R code chunk that generates a plot might look like this:







Format a Document
Quarto provides various output options for code chunks, allowing users to control how code and its results appear in the final document. These options are essential for tailoring the presentation of computational content, whether in reports, blogs, or interactive documents. The key settings for code chunk outputs are specified within chunk options, which are placed inside {} after the triple back-ticks (```) that define the code block. Users can modify these options to show or hide code, display only the results, format output styling, or manage figure properties.
One of the most commonly used options is echo, which controls whether the source code is displayed in the rendered output. Setting echo: false hides the code while still displaying the results, making it useful for polished reports where only the output matters. Conversely, eval determines whether the code is executed at all—when set to eval: false, the code appears in the document but does not run, useful for showing examples without executing them. Another key option, include, determines whether both the code and its results are included in the output; setting include: false ensures neither appear in the final document, useful for background computations.
For controlling how figures and tables appear, Quarto provides options like fig-width, fig-height, and fig-align, which adjust the size and alignment of plots. Additionally, message and warning options allow users to suppress or display messages and warnings generated by code execution. Quarto also supports output options tailored to specific formats, such as using code-fold: true to enable collapsible code sections in HTML documents, enhancing readability for interactive reports. By leveraging these output settings, users can fine-tune the presentation of their computational content, ensuring clarity and relevance in their Quarto documents.







Render a Document










The rendering process in Quarto converts a .qmd file into a fully formatted document, such as a PDF or Word (.docx) file, by processing the Markdown content, executing embedded code chunks, and applying the specified output format settings. This process ensures that the final document integrates both text and computational results in a structured, visually appealing manner. Rendering can be performed using the Quarto command line (quarto render myfile.qmd) or through an IDE like RStudio, where users can select the desired output format.
To generate a PDF, Quarto relies on LaTeX, meaning you must have a LaTeX distribution (such as TeX Live, TinyTeX, or MiKTeX) installed on your system. When rendering a PDF, Quarto converts the Markdown content into LaTeX and then compiles it into a .pdf file. Users can customize the output using LaTeX templates and options such as pdf-engine: xelatex for additional font support. The YAML header might look like this:
For a Word document, Quarto generates a .docx file by converting the Markdown and code output into a Word-compatible format. Unlike PDFs, Word documents allow for easier post-rendering edits, making them ideal for collaborative reports. The rendering process ensures that tables, figures, and code output are correctly formatted, and users can apply custom Word templates by specifying a reference document (reference-doc). The YAML header for Word output might look like this:
During the rendering process, Quarto executes code chunks (if present), embeds their results in the document, and applies formatting rules based on the specified output format. Once completed, the final file is saved in the output directory, ready for distribution or further editing. This flexible rendering system allows users to produce high-quality documents tailored to their needs, whether for publication, collaboration, or presentation.








Activity 1
Download the CSV files below to begin the assignment. Recreate the example provided and configure a PDF or Word document to continue editing your report produced in Quarto to ensure it is of high quality for submission.
Download Pokedex 1
Download Pokedex 2
Download Incomplete Activity Example
Download Complete Activity Example


Activity 2
Now that you’ve understood how everything works produce an original report in Quarto based on your research and render the document as a Word or PDF for final submission.

title: Region 4 : Sinnoh
text:
Sinnoh is a mountainous region inspired by Japan’s northern island of Hokkaido. Characterized by its cold climate, rugged terrain, and deep mythological roots, Sinnoh presents a more ancient and mysterious atmosphere than previous regions. The region is dominated by Mt. Coronet, a massive mountain range that bisects the land and plays a central role in Sinnoh’s geography and lore. The region’s landscape includes snowy peaks, deep caves, dense forests, and expansive lakes, reflecting a world shaped by ancient natural forces. The varied climate adds an extra layer of environmental storytelling, with locations like Snowpoint City feeling utterly isolated due to constant snowfall.
Sinnoh’s inspiration extends beyond geography, incorporating rich mythological and creation-based themes. The region’s lore is deeply connected to Pokémon deities like Dialga, Palkia, and Arceus, which are linked to time, space, and existence. Ancient sites such as the Spear Pillar and the Celestic Ruins suggest a civilization that revered these legendary Pokémon as divine beings. This blend of history, legend, and geography makes Sinnoh a region steeped in mysticism, encouraging players to explore and uncover the secrets of the Pokémon universe with a sense of intrigue and eagerness.

title: Region 4 : Sinnoh
text:
Pokémon Type Distribution









This demonstration explores the distribution of Pokémon types across different regions, revealing how geography and environment influence the Pokémon world. By analyzing type frequency by region, users can identify patterns in how certain types thrive in specific landscapes. The interactive visualizations allow trainers to compare regional ecosystems, uncover trends, and gain a deeper understanding of the relationship between Pokémon habitats and their elemental traits. Designed for educators, researchers, and enthusiasts, this resource bridges the gap between game-play and data analysis, offering an engaging and accessible way to explore Pokémon metadata.
Understanding the distribution of Pokémon types across different regions provides valuable insight into how geography and environment shape the Pokémon world. By analyzing type frequency by region, we can identify patterns in how certain types thrive in specific landscapes. This analysis highlights the ecological diversity within each region and deepens our understanding of how Pokémon adapt to their surroundings. Beyond identifying patterns, this analysis enhances strategic decision-making for trainers and researchers. Understanding which types are most common in each region can help trainers anticipate challenges, build balanced teams, and appreciate the environmental influences on Pokémon availability. For researchers, these insights provide a deeper look into how the Pokémon world mirrors real-world biodiversity, reinforcing the connection between habitat, adaptation, and survival. By engaging with this data, users can uncover new perspectives on the Pokémon universe and explore the dynamic relationship between nature and Pokémon distribution.
